Nikolaus Emil Wirth

Biography

Niklaus Emil Wirth, born 15 February 1934 in Winterthur, is a Swiss computer scientist. In 1959 he earned a Bachelor of Science degree in electronic engineering at the “Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, Zürich” ( ETH Zürich). In 1960 he got a Master of Science from the “ Université Laval, Canada”, after that in 1963 he was awarded a PhD in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science from the “University of California, Berkeley”.
From 1963 to 1967 he was an assistant professor at the “Stanford University” and at the “ETH Zürich”. From 1968 to 1999 he was a professor of informatics at the “ETH Zürich”.
He had also worked for the IFIP (International Federation for Information Processing) where he developed some international standards in programming and informatics. He was also in a group in charge of maintaining and supporting the programming language ALGOL 60 and ALGOL 68.

Research

He won the Turing Award in 1984 for:
“Developing a sequence of innovative computer languages” He developed 5 major language in just 22 years and in order they are Euler (1965), ALGOL W (1966), Pascal (1970), Modula (1975) and Oberon (1987).

Euler is born as an extension and generalization of ALGOL 60 with the goal of: Benign simple yet more flexible, Useful, Process with reasonable efficiency, Definable with rigorous formality.
ALGOL W was the successor of ALGOL 60, it was pretty simple in fact it added some data types, introduced the while statement and replaced the switch with the case statement.
Then he built Pascal which is an imperatve and procedural programming language, this language was designed to encurage good programming practices using structured programming and data structuring.
Modula is then a descendant of Pascal, its main innovation is a module system, used for grouping set of related declaration into a single program unit.
Last but not least we have Oberno which was the last programming language in the ALGOL-like family of programming language. Oberon was developed with the idea of increasing the power of Modula-2 but at the same time decreasing its complexiy.

Turing Award 1984

In memory of A.M. Turing
